articles.headline: Women in a Man’s World
articles.snippet: Irene Dorner, chief executive of HSBC USA, says the few women in the upper levels of Wall Street should have been better role models for the generation that followed.
articles.abstract: Irene Dorner, chief executive of HSBC USA, says the few women in the upper levels of Wall Street should have been better role models for the generation that followed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Irene Dorner blames herself — and her female colleagues — for the lack of women on Wall Street.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Sets Rules for Disclosures Using Social Media
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission cleared companies’ use of Facebook and Twitter for important announcements, following an investigation into a social media post by Netflix’s chief executive.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission cleared companies’ use of Facebook and Twitter for important announcements, following an investigation into a social media post by Netflix’s chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: 8:34 p.m. | Updated Chief executives can now feel free to post, blog or tweet — as long as they inform investors about their social media strategy first.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Investments in Education May Be Misdirected
articles.snippet: Some economists say the government should focus on programs for infants and toddlers, which may be better at reducing inequalities between the rich and the poor.
articles.abstract: Some economists say the government should focus on programs for infants and toddlers, which may be better at reducing inequalities between the rich and the poor.
articles.lead_paragraph: James Heckman is one of the nation’s top economists studying human development. Thirteen years ago, he shared the Nobel for economics. In February, he stood before the annual meeting of the Nebraska Chamber of Commerce and Industry, showed the assembled business executives a chart, and demolished the United States’ entire approach to education.

articles.headline: J.C. Penney Slashes Pay of Its Chief
articles.snippet: In a sign of dissatisfaction at the troubled retail chain, the board of J.C. Penney gave Ron Johnson and other top executives no cash bonuses for 2012.
articles.abstract: In a sign of dissatisfaction at the troubled retail chain, the board of J.C. Penney gave Ron Johnson and other top executives no cash bonuses for 2012.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a clear sign of its dissatisfaction with the direction of the company, the board of J. C. Penney gave its chief executive, Ron Johnson, a pay cut of almost 97 percent, to $1.9 million, for 2012, according to a regulatory filing on Tuesday.

articles.headline: In Mexican Villages, Few Are Left to Dream of U.S.
articles.snippet: Some American lawmakers worry that a pathway to citizenship could encourage illegal immigration, but in some parts of Mexico there seem to be few people remaining to come.
articles.abstract: Some American lawmakers worry that a pathway to citizenship could encourage illegal immigration, but in some parts of Mexico there seem to be few people remaining to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL CARGADERO, Mexico — The pretty houses in the hills here, with their bright paint and new additions, clearly display the material benefits of having millions of workers move to the United States over the past few decades. But these simple homes also reveal why another huge exodus would be unlikely: the bulk of them are empty.

articles.headline: Addictive Animal Webcams Get Network Attention
articles.snippet: Animal Planet’s live Internet stream is promoting 10 additional Web channels this week, including webcams for ants, penguins and even cockroaches.
articles.abstract: Animal Planet’s live Internet stream is promoting 10 additional Web channels this week, including webcams for ants, penguins and even cockroaches.
articles.lead_paragraph: The average visitor to the Kitten Cam on Animal Planet’s Web site has a hard time leaving. The live Internet stream of felines has been watched more than 25 million times since it started last September. The average person, seemingly transfixed by the cuteness, stays on the page for 18 minutes and 50 seconds.

articles.headline: Retailers Track Employee Thefts in Vast Databases
articles.snippet: Databases that are used by major retailers to prevent workers accused of stealing from getting another job are increasingly under scrutiny from labor lawyers and federal regulators.
articles.abstract: Databases that are used by major retailers to prevent workers accused of stealing from getting another job are increasingly under scrutiny from labor lawyers and federal regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing a wave of employee theft, retailers across the country have helped amass vast databases of workers accused of stealing and are using that information to keep employees from working again in the industry.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: A Debate in the Open on the Fed
articles.snippet: On Tuesday night, Charles L. Evans and Jeffrey M. Lacker, two Federal Reserve officials who disagree most sharply about the Fed’s current policy, engaged in a public debate.
articles.abstract: On Tuesday night, Charles L. Evans and Jeffrey M. Lacker, two Federal Reserve officials who disagree most sharply about the Fed’s current policy, engaged in a public debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Federal Reserve officials regularly air their views in public speeches, but they rarely engage in public debates. On Tuesday night, two of the officials who disagree most sharply about the Fed’s current policy did just that.

articles.headline: Taliban Assault on Afghan Compound Leaves Dozens Dead
articles.snippet: In one of the war’s deadliest insurgent attacks, nine Taliban fighters stormed a government compound, killing at least 44 people and wounding more than 100 in a hostage standoff.
articles.abstract: In one of the war’s deadliest insurgent attacks, nine Taliban fighters stormed a government compound, killing at least 44 people and wounding more than 100 in a hostage standoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In one of the deadliest insurgent attacks in the decade-long war in Afghanistan, nine Taliban fighters dressed as Afghan soldiers stormed a government compound in the western part of the country on Wednesday morning, killing at least 44 people and wounding more than 100 in a hostage standoff.
